text: Family Member 2: I saw here when I… Patient: She seems good. Family Member 2: Who’s that, K___? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And he – when he saw me he had been through the XTANDI treatment and had started showing signs of progression. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we did tissue testing because one of the ways of resistance is if they had that P10 loss which your tissue did. And that’s why we put you on this uh medication that at least you’ve tolerated amazingly well. I mean you really haven’t had any side effects, haven’t felt any different, managed to keep up with everything you want to do. So that’s been remarkable. The PSA last couple of times as we discussed last time has been going up. Okay. One of my concerns is if it keeps going up but the scans don’t change, do we stay the same course? And honestly for how well you’re doing, that’s what I’m tempted to do. Okay. If however your bone scan shows me new areas or things growing then we are going to stop this treatment and go to something else. Patient: I see. Doctor: Now as we sort of discussed a little bit, the something else could either be going back and doing chemotherapy with Dr. K____ okay that’s a potential option. And, or if we want to give it one more try with doing a different kind of hormonal therapy, we have a new hormone therapy agent that we are testing here you know that’s been through multiple people who have had it and there’s been some promising results initially so I think that would be another option. Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But you know so those are probably the potential choices. The third possible choice and that would depend on your CAT scans had some lymph nodes though that were seen so there is a study with a combination of two different therapies. Okay? One is the Xofigo which is a radiation treatment that’s approved. You’ve probably heard of it I know.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So as you follow up with the lung doctors and then Dr. G__ and I just need to know who’s going to order the scans to say the Enzalutamide is not working anymore. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And we would keep you on it if we’re going to do the immuno-therapy study. We would stop it if we were going to go to chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and then the first-in-human study—I don’t know whether we have slots right now. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: You know whether we’ve completely treated a couple of men and now we’re waiting to go up or whether or not we’re ready to go right now. So that would be a slot availability. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Your thoughts or questions about that? Patient: Well you’re going to coordinate with Dr. G. Doctor: I will coordinate with him the sort of the decision about have you progressed.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: because weirdly enough it’s IV so it’s not a pill like what you’ve been on with all of your prior treatments. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Anything else we’re missing? The other thing that’s hard about Xofigo though is that sometimes it doesn’t make the PSA go down. In fact, two-thirds of the people the PSA rises up and you’re like is this stuff in me, hello, are these guys pocketing it or what’s going on and it’s just something that happens bone wise that sometimes you just see almost the worsening of the PSA and yours is already going up so I bring that up so it won’t be like oh, my god, she’s ah, doesn’t she not know it’s higher. Patient: The conference we went to I learned about that. Doctor: Yes, you did. Patient: So that, that was well worth being there just for that. Doctor: Oh, I’m so glad. Patient: So I’m well aware of that. Doctor: Awesome. Patient: I told my kids that. I said, oh man, that’s, yeah, so I understand that. Doctor: Yeah, so you know it’s something we consider but just so you know we don’t combine the two, right.

text: Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, and, let me not forget that you’re also a candidate for a study called, Iron Man. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: Which is an international study where you would there donate once a year a tube of blood, or is it two? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And you fill out questionnaires to share with people about your journey. You know? How is this helping? Not helping? What don’t you like? Family Member: Oh. Doctor: I fill stuff out, too. And then we get all this data together- Family Member: Right. Doctor: - so that people in Brazil and Australia, and, you know, Ireland, all go and answer the same set of questionnaires. text: Patient: I have a panty liner. Just like in case I sneeze, cough. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s I mean I’m full exercising. Doctor: Uh hum. That’s okay, good. So you’re not leaking when you exercise? Patient: No, no. no. Doctor: Oh good. Okay, so really going forward, there are sort of two approaches that folks take. The standard of care is that you um would get uh radiation to your pelvis, uh and most people, given the amount of disease you have down there, we also recommend that you get hormone therapy with the radiation. Um uh, so one standard of care would be radiation alone; the second standard of care would be radiation plus hormone therapy generally for two years, which sucks, quite frankly. Family Member: Hormone therapy does? Doctor: Yeah, because it castrates you. It puts you into menopause. And we can talk some more about that. The um uh - another approach, so if we do that; let’s just focus on that, knowing that the cancer is down here in the pelvis, if you look at all the guys that get treated with radiation plus hormones and you look five years from now- Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: everybody’s alive, okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Half the guys have their cancer come back, meaning they weren’t cured by the surgery, radiation and hormones. Half of the guys are cured by the hormones and radiation. You know it sort of mops up what’s left. Okay, so at minimum the standard of care is for you to do radiation plus hormones. I can tell you why they have the hormones. If they do the radiation alone, only thirty percent of the guys are cured five years from now.

text: Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-? Doctor: It’s supposed to be but I think the question is you know for the extra twenty or thirty thousand dollars that it costs- Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: -is that truly better than what the regulation radiation is going to afford because it’s not the old time radiation. The radiation you got is still image guided. It’s still blocked off. So those studies are ongoing. And that’s why not every center and not every state has protons. Because the cost is just astronomical- Family Member: Really. Doctor: -and not every insurance company is really paying for it. And you don’t know if it’s better. So this issue comes around a lot because of prostate. So protons wanted to replace, you know, oh, and I going to save the bladder or anything else. And that data doesn’t show it to be better necessarily. So it’s a big fight between the radiation guys. They’re trying to figure that out themselves. Um, but I don’t know. I think it’s good technology. So I think if needed, if it was a really tough spot or really small area I think it’s reasonable. But you had many spots that the radiation had to go after so I’m not sure that much of an advantage would have been gained. Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time- Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: I thought that was concentrating on that bundle that was in the lumbar region. Doctor: Yep. It was. Patient: It wasn’t, it wasn’t throughout where I have cancer throughout the spine. Doctor: Well, it’s, it’s, kind of altogether. You know? So it’s the lumbar, it’s the lower lumbar is where your- Patient: Radiation treatment was.

text: Patient: Yeah. Well, I noticed it hurt, so I tried to take care of it. Iced it and everything else and then about a week later I noticed my leg was swelling and then it moved down my leg into my ankle. Doctor: And you went to the emergency room? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they found it Patient: They all freaked out. Even the doctors, everybody. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Because it was- it ran from here all the way down to my ankle. Yeah. Doctor: So you know, being on the blood thinner for at least three months is sort of the minimum that we have to do. Patient: Right. Doctor: And we could potentially stop it. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then you know, your body if your leg swells up again, that may tell us that we need to really use it for life.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
